title: How to Paint Exterior Siding

steps.headline: Cover the nearby ground and vegetation with drop cloths.
steps.description: These can be found at most hardware stores starting at around $1.

steps.headline: Rub the siding with a cloth to clean off any powdery paint pigment and mildew.
Test the existing paint for lead.
steps.description: This is only necessary for homes built prior to the 1980s in the United States. If your home is not in the United States, check with your local consumer safety agency for information. Use a lead test kit, which can be obtained at some retail stores or online for approximately $13. If lead is present, contact a licensed lead abatement specialist.

steps.headline: Mix 1 cup (240 ml) of chlorine bleach with 1 cup (240 ml) of Trisodium Phosphate (TSP) and 1 gallon (3.78 liters) of water.
steps.description: Be sure to wear gloves while doing this.

steps.headline: Soak an abrasive sponge in the solution and scrub the siding.
Rinse the siding with a garden hose.
Apply 1 coat of acrylic primer.
steps.description: This can be purchased at most hardware and home improvement stores.

steps.headline: Pour thoroughly mixed paint into a bucket.
steps.description: Many hardware and home improvement stores offer paint mixing services. To lighten a paint color, add white paint as needed until the desired color is reached. To darken a paint color, add black paint to darker colors and gray paint to lighter colors. A general rule of thumb is to stay within 2 shades of the original color. To intensify a color, add more of the base color.

steps.headline: Dip a 2-2.5 inch (5.08-6.35 cm) nylon or polyester brush into the paint.
Start at the top and paint horizontally along the top and bottom of each sideboard.

text:
Cover the nearby ground and vegetation with drop cloths. These can be found at most hardware stores starting at around $1. Rub the siding with a cloth to clean off any powdery paint pigment and mildew. Test the existing paint for lead. This is only necessary for homes built prior to the 1980s in the United States. If your home is not in the United States, check with your local consumer safety agency for information. Use a lead test kit, which can be obtained at some retail stores or online for approximately $13. If lead is present, contact a licensed lead abatement specialist. Mix 1 cup (240 ml) of chlorine bleach with 1 cup (240 ml) of Trisodium Phosphate (TSP) and 1 gallon (3.78 liters) of water. Be sure to wear gloves while doing this. Soak an abrasive sponge in the solution and scrub the siding. Rinse the siding with a garden hose. Allow the siding to dry. Apply 1 coat of acrylic primer. This can be purchased at most hardware and home improvement stores. Pour thoroughly mixed paint into a bucket. Many hardware and home improvement stores offer paint mixing services. To lighten a paint color, add white paint as needed until the desired color is reached. To darken a paint color, add black paint to darker colors and gray paint to lighter colors. A general rule of thumb is to stay within 2 shades of the original color. To intensify a color, add more of the base color. Dip a 2-2.5 inch (5.08-6.35 cm) nylon or polyester brush into the paint. Start at the top and paint horizontally along the top and bottom of each sideboard.
